a. Demonstrate the use of aseptic technique.
b. Demonstrate proper use of the microscope and slide preparation techniques.
c. Name and describe the different types of stains used in microbiology.
d. Name and describe the types of culture media and explain how each type provides the nutritional requirements for microbial growth.
e. Demonstrate proper techniques for isolating, culturing, and staining microorganisms.
4. Describe the classification, morphology, characteristics, pathology and benefits associated with bacteria. (L)
a. Compare and contrast the characteristics of eukaryotic and prokaryotic cell types.
b. Describe the taxonomic criteria used to place bacteria into related groups.
c. Identify and describe the structure and function of internal and external bacterial cell components.
d. Identify the most common pathogenic bacteria.
e. Investigate the beneficial aspects of bacteria in medicine, industry, and everyday life.
5. Describe the classification, morphology, characteristics and pathology associated with viruses. (L)
a. Describe the general characteristics of viruses.
b. Identify and describe the major characteristics of each group of viruses.
c. Describe the mechanisms of replication in virulent and temperate phages.
d. Identify the most common viruses and the diseases associated with each.
6. Describe the classification, morphology, characteristics, benefits and associated pathology of fungi. (L)
a. Describe the general characteristics of fungi.
b. Identify the major groups of fungi and describe the classification of each group.
c. Identify the most common types of pathogenic fungi and the diseases associated with each.
d. Describe the economic importance of fungi.
7. Describe the classification, morphology, characteristics and associated pathology of protists. (L)
a. Describe the characteristics that distinguish protists from other microorganisms.
b. Describe the classification of protists.
c. Identify the most common pathogenic protists and the diseases associated with each.

text: Molecular Biology

children.text: 1. Utilize critical thinking and scientific problem solving in designing and performing biological research and experimentation. (L, P, E)
a. Demonstrate the proper use and care for scientific equipment used in molecular biology.
b. Observe and practice safe procedures in the classroom and laboratory.
c. Apply the components of scientific processes and methods in the classroom and laboratory investigations.
d. Communicate results of scientific investigations in oral, written, and graphic form.
2. Review the structure, functions, and processes of the cell involved in maintaining life. (L, P)
a. Review organic compounds and biochemical processes in the cell.
b. Review the structure and function of the cell.
3. Investigate the structure and function of DNA. (L, P)
a. Describe the contributions of various scientists to the discovery and understanding that DNA is the genetic material.
b. Describe the organization of DNA.
c. Summarize the steps in replication.
4. Analyze the roles of DNA and RNA in protein synthesis. (L, P)
a. State the central dogma of molecular biology.
b. Discuss the processes of transcription and translation.
c. Compare and contrast the roles of three types of RNA including codons and anticodons.
d. Describe the effects of mutations on protein synthesis.
5. Describe the mechanisms of gene expression in prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells. (L, P)
a. Investigate inducible and repressable operon models of gene expression in prokaryotic cells.
b. Investigate the levels of control of gene expression in eukaryotic cells including pre-transcriptional, post-transcriptional, pre-translational, and post-translational factors.
6. Investigate the basic tools and techniques used to manipulate DNA. (L, P)
a. Describe the basic steps in genetic engineering experiments.
b. Explore how scientists use restriction enzymes.
c. Explore the role of vectors in genetic research.
d. Discuss how transformation techniques are used.
e. Identify practical uses of biotechnology.
f. Evaluate the moral and ethical issues related to genetic engineering.

text: Botany

children.text: 1. Utilize critical thinking and scientific problem solving in designing and performing biological research and experimentation. (L, P, E)
a. Demonstrate the proper use and care for scientific equipment used in botany.
b. Observe and practice safe procedures in the classroom and laboratory.
c. Apply the components of scientific processes and methods in the classroom and laboratory investigations.
d. Communicate results of scientific investigations in oral, written, and graphic form.
2. Examine plant cell structures and functions to include the formation of specialized tissue. (L)
a. Identify the major organelles, their structures and functions.
b. Determine the role of pigments.
c. Identify the cellular basis of tissues and explore the functions of specialized root, stem, and leaf tissues.
3. Identify plant products that impact humans. (L, P)
a. Examine the chemical compounds extracted from plants, to include drugs.
b. Discuss the impact of the timber industry on local and national economy.
c. Determine the origin of a wide variety of assorted plant products – spices, herbs, fossil fuels, fibers.
4. Compare and contrast the characteristics of different plant divisions. (L)
a. Explore the differences and similarities of the nonvascular plants including mosses and liverworts.
b. Describe the differences and similarities of the non-seed-bearing vascular plants, including ferns and horsetails.
c. Explore the characteristics of seed-bearing vascular plants.
5. Identify the major structures of seed-bearing plants, relating them to overall plant function. (L)
a. Identify the major vegetative structures and/or their modifications in angiosperms and gymnosperms.
b. Identify the reproductive structures, and their modifications, in angiosperms and gymnosperms.
c. Compare and contrast the vegetative organs of monocots, herbaceous dicots, and woody dicots.
6. Analyze the physical and chemical processes of plants. (L, P)
a. Compare and contrast the relationships of photosynthesis, cellular respiration, and translocation to overall plant survival.
b. Explore the importance of soil type to overall plant survival, including mineral nutrition and air/water balance.
c. Explain the mechanism of water movement in plants.
d. Explain the effects of environmental conditions such as light, heat, water content, and wind on plant survival.
e. Identify the physical response of plants to sunlight, day length and gravity (tropisms).
7. Identify the structures and processes of sexual and asexual reproduction in plants. (L)
a. Explain the concept of alternation of generations.
b. Compare and contrast the structures and mechanisms involved in sexual and asexual reproduction in selected plant species.
c. Identify the different methods of seed distribution in plants.
8. Describe the ecological importance of plants. (L, E)
a. Compare and contrast plant structure, form, and adaptation and describe how each relates to habitat (biome).
b. Identify concepts such as nutrient cycling, succession, natural selection, competition, and symbiosis that influence/alter plant stability within the environment.
c. Analyze the effects of human activity on the plant world.
9. Apply the modern classification scheme utilized in naming plants. (L)
a. Explain the classification scheme used in botany.
b. Apply the concept of classification by using a dichotomous key to identify a native Mississippi plant.
10. Explore the principles of plant genetics. (L)
a. Explain the results of monohybrid and dihybrid crosses.
b. Explain the effects of genetic engineering of plants on society.
c. Explore the current trends in biotechnology of plants.
d. Describe alternative methods of plant propagation.

text: Zoology

children.text: 1. Utilize critical thinking and scientific problem solving in designing and performing biological research and experimentation. (L, P, E)
a. Demonstrate the proper use and care for scientific equipment used in zoology.
b. Observe and practice safe procedures in the classroom and laboratory.
c. Apply the components of scientific processes and methods in the classroom and laboratory investigations.
d. Communicate results of scientific investigations in oral, written, and graphic form.
2. Review the general characteristics and phylogeny of animals. (L)
a. Explain the levels of organization of structures in animals (cells, tissues, organs and systems).
b. Describe the characteristics of animals that distinguish them from other kingdoms.
c. Discuss adaptations of the major phyla that lead to their survival.
d. Discuss the phylogenic sequencing of the nine major phyla.
e. Review the classification scheme used in zoology.

3. Compare and contrast the anatomy and physiology of the 9 major phyla of the animal kingdom with special attention to:(L) symmetry, digestion, support, germ layers, circulation, locomotion, body plan, coordination, reproduction, embryonic development, excretion
3. Compare and contrast the anatomy and physiology of the 9 major phyla of the animal kingdom with special attention to: (L)
symmetry
germ layers
body plan
embryonic development
digestion
circulation
coordination
excretion
support
locomotion
reproduction
4. Relate the life histories of groups of animals to the success of the groups. (L)
a. Discuss the advantages and disadvantages of both asexual and sexual reproduction.
b. Illustrate life cycles of various groups of animals.
5. Explain how behavior and symbiosis are related to the success of a group of animals. (L)
a. Discuss, giving specific examples of, division of labor within a group of animals.
b. Compare and contrast the degree of parental care given in groups of animals.
c. Discuss mutualism, communalism, parasitism and mimicry, giving specific examples of each.

text: Aquatic Science

children.text: 1. Utilize critical thinking and scientific problem solving in designing and performing biological research and experimentation. (L, P, E)
a. Demonstrate the proper use and care for scientific equipment used aquatic science.
b. Observe and practice safe procedures in the classroom and laboratory.
c. Apply the components of scientific processes and methods in the classroom and laboratory investigations.
d. Communicate results of scientific investigations in oral, written, and graphic form.
2. Analyze the physical and chemical properties of water and how they affect the organisms that live in it. (L, P)
a. Investigate the causes and characteristics of tides.
b. Describe the physical principles of waves and currents.
c. Characterize the physical and chemical parameters of dissolved O2, pH, temperature, and salinity through analysis of different water column depths/zones.
d. Explore the role of bodies of water as they relate to weather.
e. Describe the various biogeochemical cycles.
3. Describe major geologic features of specific aquatic environments. (L, E)
a. Identify the causes and effects of erosion.
b. Define terminology associated with plate tectonics.
c. Distinguish among rise, slope, elevation, and depth.
d. Compare the formation of dunes, reefs, barrier/volcanic islands, and coastal/flood plains.
e. Describe watershed formation and its relationship to bodies of fresh water.
4. Describe the biodiversity and interactions among aquatic life. (L)
a. Analyze the adaptations of representative organisms to aquatic environments.
b. Analyze the relationship of organisms in food chains/webs within aquatic environments.
c. Calculate and interpret population data with regard to aquatic organisms.
d. Identify representative examples that illustrate various aquatic reproductive strategies.
e. Compare and contrast characteristics of planktonic, nektonic, and benthic organisms.
f. Classify different aquatic organisms using dichotomous keys.
g. Compare and contrast aquatic producers, consumers, and decomposers.
5. Examine the unique properties of selected aquatic ecosystems. (L, E)
a. Describe the abiotic and biotic characteristics of a barrier island, coral reef, and ocean.
b. Describe the abiotic and biotic characteristics of a river, stream, lake, pond, and swamp.
c. Describe the abiotic and biotic characteristics of a bay, sound, estuary, and marsh.
d. Describe the symbiotic relationships in an aquatic ecosystem.
6. Identify the impact of natural and human activity on aquatic ecosystems. (L, E)
a. Identify various sources of pollution in aquatic environments.
b. Describe the effects of natural phenomena such as hurricanes, floods, or drought on aquatic habitats.
c. Describe a variety of methods of environmental management and stewardship.
d. Evaluate the effects of urbanization on aquatic ecosystems.
e. Describe the effects of bodies of water on human cultural development.
7. Investigate applications of modern technology in aquatic systems. (L, P)
a. Identify various careers related to aquatic science.
b. Discuss the advantages and disadvantages of the use of modern technology within aquatic science (mariculture and aquaculture).
c. Relate the contribution of aquatic technology to industry and government.

text: Environmental Science

children.text: 1. Utilize critical thinking and scientific problem solving in designing and performing biological research and experimentation. (L, P, E)
a. Demonstrate the proper use and care for scientific equipment used in environmental science.
b. Observe and practice safe procedures in the classroom and laboratory.
c. Apply the components of scientific processes and methods in the classroom and laboratory investigations.
d. Communicate results of scientific investigations in oral, written, and graphic form.
2. Explain the flow of matter and energy in ecosystems. (L, P)
a. Investigate the role of biotic and abiotic factors within habitats, ecosystems and biomes.
b. Identify indigenous plants and animals and their roles in different ecosystems.
c. Describe food chains and food webs within an ecosystem.
d. Predict how the introduction, removal or reintroduction of an organism may alter the food chain, change populations, and impact the biodiversity of ecosystems.
e. Investigate chemical cycles within ecosystems.
3. Describe the relationships and changes within an ecosystem. (L, E)
a. Explain how a species adapts to its niche.
b. Relate population dynamics (natural selection, exponential growth, predator/prey) to carrying capacity and limiting factors.
c. Evaluate the effects of biotic and abiotic factors on local ecosystems and biomes.
d. Describe the process of primary and secondary succession.
e. Analyze and describe the effects of events such as fires, hurricanes, deforestation, mining, population growth and industry on environments.
4. Investigate the major biomes of the world ecosystems. (L, E)

a. Describe the following biomes to include location, climate, adaptations and diversity.
  • desert
  • tundra
  • grassland
  • savannah
  • coniferous forest
  • deciduous forest
  • rain forest
  • rain forest
  • aquatic enveronments
b. Illustrate where the eight major biomes occur.
5. Summarize the interrelationships among the resources and human activities in the local environment. (L, E)
a. Identify sources, use, quality and conservation of water.
b. Identify renewable and non-renewable resources.
c. Evaluate the impact of human activity and technology on the lithosphere, hydrosphere, and atmosphere.
d. Identify the effects of pollution (water, noise, air, etc.) on the ecosystem.
e. Describe how communities have restored ecosystems.
6. Research various environmental topics, such as major events, careers, history, and significant contributions. (L, P, E)

text: Geology

children.text: 1. Investigate the Earth internal and external components. (E)
a. Identify the layers and sublayers of the atmosphere and of the earth.
b. Describe the basic kinds of rocks and their subtypes.
c. Discuss the characteristics of mineral deposit types and methods of formation.
2. Investigate the interaction between the Earth internal and external components. (E, P)
a. Determine the effects of physical weathering (atmospheric, glacial, etc.).
b. Examine the effects of chemical weathering (acid rain, etc.).
c. Discuss the transfer of energy.
d. Examine the interaction of erupting volcanoes and the atmosphere.
e. Describe the various cycles (water, carbon dioxide, nitrogen, etc.).
3. Investigate plate tectonics. (E)
a. Explore the theories of plate development and continental drift.
b. Explain the process that power crustal movements.
c. Identify and describe the types of crustal movements and their resulting landforms.
d. Locate areas of crustal movement around the world.
e. Explain the processes that create earthquakes and volcanoes.
f. Develop an emergency preparedness plan for natural disasters associated with crustal movement.
4. Investigate local and regional geological areas. (E)
a. Identify major geological features in Mississippi (the Delta, the Coastal Plains, etc.)
b. Research geological activity of the New Madrid Fault line.
5. Explore the geological timetable. (E)
a. Compare and contrast the relative and absolute age of the Earth (radiometric dating, index of fossil layers, etc.).
b. Describe the differences among eras, periods, and epochs as recorded in the geological time scale.
c. Explore the connections among geological history, landforms, and presence of minerals.

text: Astronomy

children.text: 1. Discuss the history of astronomy. (E, P)
a. Recognize observations that significantly contributed to the understanding of the solar system prior to the telescope development.
b. Explain how the invention of the telescope impacted the development of modern astronomy.
c. Trace the development of models to predict planetary motion (Ptolemy, Copernicus, Kepler and Newton).
d. Explore theories of the universe origin.
2. Investigate the technologies and instruments (optical telescopes, radio telescopes, space probes, artificial satellites, etc.) used in ground and space based astronomy. (E)
a. Differentiate between various methods of observation.
b. Explore the methods used in determining the characteristics of our solar system components (spectra, probes, Doppler, etc.).
3. Investigate Newton Universal Gravitation Law and Kepler Laws. (E, P)
a. Describe the structure and gravitational interactions of a planetary system according to Newton Laws of Motion and Gravitation.
b. Utilize the Universal Gravitational constant to calculate the orbital velocity in a two body system.
c. Describe the motion and interactions of a planetary system according to Kepler Laws.
d. Calculate period, distance from the sun, and/or velocity of a planet using Kepler Laws.
4. Investigate and compare data about celestial bodies in our solar system. (E)
a. Explore the motion of celestial bodies (planetary rotation and revolution, comets, asteroids, moons, sun, etc.)
b. Compare and contrast internal and surface components of celestial bodies.
c. Track the Earth moon over an extended period of time.
d. Examine current theories, proposals and supporting data of celestial bodies in our solar system.
e. Describe the origin, composition and structure of asteroids, meteors and comets.
5. Investigate the sun, other stars and star systems. (E)
a. Discuss star classification (by size and magnitude) and types of stars.
b. Examine the origin and demise of stars.
c. Research the composition, energy production and solar-magnetic activity of stars.
d. Measure distance using triangulation and parallax methods.
e. Describe star systems visible from earth.
6. Describe the universe in terms of its diverse components and their relationships. (E)
a. Identify types of galaxies, proximity of galaxies, the name of Earth galaxy, etc.
b. Research recent reports on the structure of the universe.
c. Examine components of the celestial sphere.

text: Aerospace Studies

children.text: 1. Explore the histroy of flight. (E)
a. Identify and discuss achievements of early aviators.
b. Discuss applications of flight.
c. Investigate flight as personal recreation.
2. Describe principles of aerodynamics and flight control. (E,P)
a. Describe how the flow of air over an airfoil creates lift.
b. Discuss relationships among forces (lift, weight, thrust, drag) and their affects on flight.
3. Discuss the design and function of major aircraft structures, insturments, and life support systems.
a. Identify the airplane's structural components and instruments and their purposes.
b. Describe the designs, functions, and uses of various flight control surfaces.
c. Relate how the location of center of gravity affects flight stability.
d. Discuss the function and necessity of life-support systems on aircraft.
4. Compare the various methods of aircraft propulsion. (E, P)
a. Describe the operation of reciprocating, turbine, and jet engines.
b. Trace the development of aircraft propulsion systems.
c. Use the combined gas laws to calculate the expansion ratio of gases in an engine.
5. Use the instruments and perform calculations involved in navigation. (E)
a. Locate a point on the globe from its global coordinates.
b. Plot a point-point course using a sectional map.

text: Organic Chemistry

children.text: 1. Apply IUPAC nomenclature, and draw or recognize the structure of aliphatic, aromatic, and cyclic hydrocarbon compounds. (P, L)
a. Describe the nomenclature system of naming hydrocarbon compounds.
b. Draw structures of hydrocarbon compounds.
c. Explore isomerism in hydrocarbon compounds.
d. Relate structure to physical and chemical properties of hydrocarbons.
2. Write, complete and classify common reactions for aliphatic, aromatic, and cyclic hydrocarbons. (P)
a. Write and identify equations representing oxidation reactions.
b. Write and identify equations representing substitution reactions.
c. Write and identify equations representing dehydrogenation reactions.
d. Write and identify equations representing addition reactions.
3. Describe functional groups (alcohols, ethers, aldehydes, ketones, carboxylic acids, esters, amines, amides, and nitriles) by their structure and chemical and physical properties. (P)
a. Recognize and draw structural formulas from functional group names, and vice-versa.
b. Describe the chemical and physical properties of compounds containing functional groups.
c. Recognize and write equations representing the transformation of one functional group into another.
4. Describe the synthesis, properties and uses of polymers. (P)
a. Define and give examples of common polymers.
b. Describe the synthesis of polymers from monomers by addition or condensations.
c. Classify plastics according to their commercial types.
d. Calculate elasticity and other polymer properties given experimental data.
5. Relate organic chemicals to their application in industry, drug manufacture, and biological chemistry. (P, L)
a. Describe common uses of polymers.
b. Explore the diversity, applications, and economics of industrial chemicals (solvents, coatings, surfactants, etc.).
c. Investigate significant biologically active compounds in terms of functional group substrate interaction.
d. Describe the use of organic compounds in medicine, drugs, and personal care products.
e. Describe the synthesis and application of compounds, which have the property to dye materials.
f. Discuss the major aspects of the production of petrochemicals.
